pageTitle: Higher temperatures could mean lower maple syrup production | The Chillicothe Gazette | chillicothegazette.com
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {29508=Maple tapping season usually starts at the end of February and runs until mid-March. The ideal conditions are sunny days with temperatures in the 50s followed by nights getting down into the 30s. The warmer days allow the sap to flow in the maple trees before slowing down in the evening. Temperature change can alter the length of tapping season and have a negative effect on Ohios annual maple syrup harvest volume, like it did last year when the warm temperatures caused the season to start earlier., 37641=No one knows if the warm winter of 2012 was a one-time anomaly or part of a permanent warming cycle, but some Ohio maple syrup producers are watching closely because temperature changes can affect, 30315=The warm 2012 winter led to a decrease in the states production from the previous years 125,000 gallons to 100,000 gallons, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. But this years number rose to 155,000 gallons as Ohio experienced a winter closer to the norm., 28155=LANCASTER — No one knows if the warm winter of 2012 was a one-time anomaly or part of a permanent warming cycle, but some Ohio maple syrup producers are watching closely because temperature changes can affect their annual yield., 32189=Nationally, maple syrup production increased 70 percent from last year to 3.25 million gallons this year and all maple syrup-producing states showed an increase in 2013 from 2012, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The USDA credits that to cooler temperatures in the early spring, which provided for a longer season of tap flow. The season averaged 37 days, up from 24 days in 2012., 72526=Copyright © 2015 archive.chillicothegazette.com. All rights reserved. Users of this site agree to the Terms of Service, Privacy Notice/Your California Privacy Rights, and Ad Choices}

textAfterTable: Source: United States Department of Agriculture and the Ohio State University Extension Office. Ohios changing climate To show how Ohios climate and environment are changing, the Media Network of Central Ohio sought concrete examples showing the states environment isnt what it used to be, regardless of the cause. During the course of a week, we will present several of these examples, but we know we cant hit them all. If you have a story about the environment to share, tell us via our Facebook page. All the stories from the series will be posted to Zanesville TimesRecorder.com/ climate as they appear online or in print. Coming Thursday Climate change could hurt Lake Eries perch population.
